citation.article-title: Natronobacterium gen. nov. and Natronococcus gen. nov., two new genera of haloalkaliphilic archaebacteria.

p.s: Description of Natronococcus gen. nov.
Natronococcus (Na.tro.no.coc'cus. natron, derived from an Arabic noun for soda; Gr.n. coccus, a berry; M.L. gen. n. Natronococcus, the soda berry)
Cells non-motile, coccoid 1-2 μm in diameter occurring in irregular clusters, pairs and single cells in liquid and on solid media.
Colonies are circular, matt, pale brown, 1-3 mm in diameter after 5-7 days at 37°C.
Cell contents are released in distilled water but cells appear intact when examined microscopically.
Gram reaction is mixed with some cells positive, some negative.
Extremely halophilic with growth occurring between 8-30% NaCl, optimum 20-22% at 37°C.
Temperature range for growth 20-50°C, optimum temperature 35-40°C.
pH range for growth 8.5-11.0, optimum 9.5.
Possesses menaquinones MK-8 and MK-8(H2) and both C20, C20 and C20, C25 diether core lipids.
Does not possess glycolipids.
Chemoorganotrophic.
Strict aerobe.
Nitrogen sources: casamino acids.
Glucose, ribose and sucrose stimulate growth.
Nitrates reduced to nitrites.
Gelatin liquefied.
Starch not hydrolysed, sulphide not produced from cysteine.
Sensitive to anisomycin, bacitracin, erythromycin and novobiocin.
Insensitive to ampicillin, chloramphenicol, polymyxin B, streptomycin, and tetracycline.
G + C content 64.0 mol % for the major DNA component.
Possesses a minor DNA component with G + C content of 55.7 mol % (buoyant density).
Possesses large plasmid c 144 kb.
Habitats: highly saline soda lakes.
Type species: Natronococcus occultus gen. et sp. nov.
